column4: How come "sudo apt-get upgrade" does not install the linux kernel update?
Does it give you any errors or warnings?
It just tells me its held back
If I use the Update GUI app, than it installs
So is it installed or not?
Using the CLI commands, it does not work....using the GUI update program, it works
Once you upgrade the kernel, you can't upgrade it again to the same version.
So if you've already upgraded it with the GUI, then you're not going to be able to upgrade it again.
it was the default kernel for 10.04, 2.6.32-21 and sudo apt-get upgrade tells me there is a 2.6.32-22 but the kernel update is being held back
Why do you say that the GUI succeeded in upgrading it?  If there's still an upgrade then the GUI didn't do it either.
Before the update, I did a "uname -a" and it shows the kernel as 2.6.32-21.  After the GUI update and a reboot, "uname -a" shows the kernel as 2.32-22.  So the GUI update did update the kernel
Try "aptitude why-not <pkg>" where <pkg> is the name of the package being held back.
OK, so if you've updated the kernel, why are you trying to re-update it from the command line?  It has already been upgraded.
Thanks!  Re-install 10.04 from scratch again and will try that CLI command.
I'm just trying to understand why the first time I ran "sudo apt-get upgrade", it didn't download and install the new kernel, 2.6.32-22
and only after I use the GUI update, did the kernel got upgraded

From the error message, it means that someone or something told apt "don't upgrade the kernel!".  You can do that manually, or another program can say "I don't work with newer versions of the kernel, so don't upgrade it."
I'm assuming the GUI just didn't tell you that the package was held, and it just upgraded it anyway.
That's correct.  The GUI didnt care and went ahead w/ the upgrade.
But since you've already upgraded it, the information that would tell you what was really going on isn't there any more.
So there probably isn't a good way to figure out now what happened.
I'm wiping out my install and starting over w/ a clean fresh install of 10.04.
OK.  I'd recommend using "aptitude" instead of "apt-get" for command line package management.
Thanks!  I'll look into it and see what are the diff between apt-get and apititude
